petitioner.name: MENACHEM BINYAMIN ZIVOTOFSKY, BY HIS PARENTS AND GUARDIANS, ARI Z. AND NAOMI SIEGMAN ZIVOTOFSKY

respondent.name:
No. 13-628.
JOHN KERRY, SECRETARY OF STATE.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument first in Case 13-628, Zivotofsky versus Kerry. Ms. Lewin.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Suppose that --  suppose that the President and the Secretary of State put on the passport the place of birth --  I've written it out -- the place of birth on this Jerusalem-born citizen's passport has been listed as Israel at the holder's request. This designation is neither an acknowledgment Alderson Reporting Company nor a declaration by the Department of State or the President of the United States that Jerusalem is within the borders of the State of Israel. Could the President, under existing statute, and the Secretary of State, under existing statute, put that statement on the passport?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But if -- if -- if Congress then passed a law saying that that statement had to come off every passport, could Congress do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Has that ever happened?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: In the history of the United States where Congress after the President had declared that it was not recognizing someone, has Congress ever recognized it? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: If you were careful to say at the outset that this is not recognition, the court of appeals decision, I think it was in the Judge Tabor concurrence, said that both parties urge upon us that they -- that the power of recognition is involved here and Congress has done it. And then, of course, the Attorney General takes -- takes the opposite position that the -- that this, A, this is recognition and, B, that's why it's void. Did you change your position here, or am I just misinterpreting the way this -- the court of appeals discussed it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The -- the -- does -- the provision is part of a section, Section And I think you're trying to read G, and so it is disassociated from the purpose that's expressed throughout 214, that is, that Jerusalem is the capital of Israel. Congress said that, and you -- you are trying to deal with a piece of one section without regard to the -- to the thrust of the whole provision, that Congress has said we think Jerusalem is the capital of Israel.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You say that. But the -- Alderson Reporting Company you say -- I've heard exactly what you said. And I think that's certainly a reasonable position. You could read this and say it doesn't really say anything about recognizing anything. But the Solicitor General of the United States, after conferring with the State Department, says, "Since Israel's founding, every President has adhered to the position that the status of Jerusalem should not be unilaterally determined by a party," and he adds, "by requiring the President to contradict his recognition position regarding Jerusalem in official communications with foreign sovereigns, the section unconstitutionally encroaches on the President's core recognition authority." So he has a different view. He thinks it is our policy not to recognize Jerusalem as the capital, which you apparently agree with, and he thinks that this does have some tendency at least to suggest the contrary. Now, I'm a judge. I'm not a foreign affairs expert. And when he tells me that, and they are foreign affairs experts in the State Department, how can I say that I'm right even if I agree with you, and they, who are in charge of foreign affairs, are wrong when they make those two statements, which certainly sound Alderson Reporting Company plausible.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I want -- and I must interject at this point because you emphasize the Taiwan example and it seems to me it's most distinguishable. Taiwan and China maintained from the beginning there is only one China, and so Taiwan is a place name. It's a region. It's in no way recognizing, no -- there's no question of recognition in the Taiwan example.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no, to go back to my question --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- which I'd like an answer to. I don't think that Taiwan is a counterexample since the policy of the State Department in that thing that's FAM, which is the Foreign Affairs Manual, says pretty clearly that if there's a dispute about the larger power, i.e., China, you always can put in your passport Alderson Reporting Company the smaller place of birth, like a city or I would think here Taiwan. So I don't hear the Department or I guess I'm saying the experts saying that the Taiwan example conflicted with their policy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: China objected to that. Did China not object to it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: China may have done -- I want an answer to this question --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- not whether China objected or didn't object or so forth. I'm not interested in that. I'm interested in what we, as judges, do when the State Department and those charged say those other things were not contrary to our recognition policy. That's what they think, and this is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'd like the first point. What am I supposed to do in respect to that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Ms. Lewin, I -- I thought your position was you couldn't care less if the State Department thinks that this is going to interfere with our relations with the Palestinians, that Congress is entitled to do what it is authorized to do under the Constitution, even when that contradicts -- let's assume they can't recognize a country, but they can declare war on a country, can't they --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- that the State Department has decided to recognize and -- and to be friendly with?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Congress can do that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And you say can do the same here. And -- and the fact that the State Department doesn't like the fact that it makes the Palestinians angry is irrelevant.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If you take that position, which explains it, then what do you think of Justice Story who writes in that, "The exercise of the prerogative of acknowledging new nations and ministers" -- and he makes clear that involves whether a city or a region is part of a country, et cetera, he says, it's an executive function. Some argue, as we -- I think we've just heard, that Congress could make that decision, too, but that hasn't been decided. And he concludes that, "A power so extensive in its reach over our foreign relations could not properly be conferred on any other than the Executive Department will admit of little doubt."

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So he is saying, of course, you have to have one person deciding such a thing, and that has to be the Executive. That's 1833, pretty knowledgeable about the founders' intent.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But what -- there is always review with the power of the purse, and there's always review with not appointing an ambassador. There -- there is review in a variety of alternative ways by Congress. It just may not be the way you prefer, that they could pass a resolution contradicting that that would have any legal course.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I suppose -- I suppose you could also say Hamilton in or whatever it was trumped Story in 1830, right? I mean, he said pretty much the exact opposite, that the recognition provision was really just a trivial formality.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Ms. Lewin --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: In any case, this is not your main point, is it? You're -- you're being either forced into or willingly yield yourself to arguing that -- against the proposition that if this is recognition, it is invalid. But your main position is this is not recognition; it just has an effect on -- on the State Department's desire to -- to make nice with the Palestinians, and your position is Congress has no -- no compulsion to -- to follow that, assuming it can't recognize.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You don't claim that this is recognition.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: If you ask -- one factual matter I'd like. I see in the record that your application for the passport asked for "Jerusalem, Israel," but that was changed. Was it changed in litigation? Was there an actual official request to change it in your application? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Answer my question. Did you apply formally to have it changed or did you just take this -- that position in litigation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: May I ask you another -- another factual question? When Menachem was born, was he issued a birth certificate by the Israeli authorities?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And the United States recognizes that as -- as a lawful exercise of Israeli authority, to issue a birth certificate for a child born in Jerusalem?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So what -- this is a question I would ask the Solicitor General, but I don't completely understand what the position of the United States is regarding Israeli sovereignty over Jerusalem. Alderson Reporting Company I understand it is the position of the United States that Israel does not exercise full sovereignty over Jerusalem, but in that -- in this instance, the issuance of a birth certificate, and others I can think of, I suspect the United States recognizes that Israel is lawfully exercising attributes of sovereignty over the territory of Jerusalem. Is that correct? So if someone -- let's say an American citizen committed a crime in Jerusalem, would the United States take the position that the Israeli government has no lawful authority to prosecute that person for the crime?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Ms. Lewin, if I can ask you, if your primary position is that this is not a recognition statute, can we talk a little bit about what it is? I mean, why -- what -- what is the design, what is the effect of this statute other than as something that goes to recognition?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But the United States Government does not usually give people that right to self-identify in this way. In other words, I think this was the Chief Justice's question in the first argument, if you're an American citizen born in Northern Ireland, you can't get the right to say Ireland. For that matter, if you are an American citizen born in Jerusalem today, you can't get the rights to say Palestine. This is a very selective vanity plate law, if we might call it that. And -- and it's selective because Congress had, it appears to me, and it's consistent with the rest of the statute, as Justice Ginsburg said, a real view that this was the self-identification it wanted. In other words, the ability of American citizens to say yes, I was born in Jerusalem, and that means I was born in Israel. That and only that self-identification is allowed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What about Palestinians who were born in Jerusalem and want to have Palestine as their place of birth? That -- that existed until 1948, that option.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Now, people can -- Palestinians cannot -- American-born Palestinians cannot do that. And that suggests that Congress had a view, and the view was that Jerusalem was properly part of Israel.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: If an American citizen is born in Barcelona, Spain, is that citizen allowed, by the State Department, to put Barcelona as place of birth? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And is that a -- is that a vanity plate for people who believe in Catalan independence?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But, again, your argument -- and you're consistent on this, your first argument is that this is not recognition. Now, suppose the State Department, and I think this is its position, says this is recognition. If we defer to the State Department's judgment, to the government's executive judgment on that point, and the government said this is recognition, and you say it isn't recognition, why doesn't the government trump? If the government -- if the Congress really wants to test its power, it can pass a law saying you must recognize Israel as being the legitimate government of Palestine, but it has not done that. And since it has not done that, it seems to me the government's argument trumps.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But you -- but you say that this isn't recognition. So the ultimate conflict is not before us and -- and, therefore, the government's policy, which says that this is recognition, should be given deference and it trumps.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I -- I guess there are competing canons here. I mean, one is, I suppose, that we listen to the State Department on matters of foreign affairs, but I suppose another one is that we do not hold a -- an act of Congress to be unconstitutional and thereby ineffective. So that seems to me a draw, doesn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So the State Department says this amounts to recognition, and Congress says whether it does or not, we want -- we want this person to be able to list Israel.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Can I --  can I give you a hypothetical, Ms. Lewin? Suppose that Congress passed a law and this law said that the Secretary of State had to send an official letter to all foreign ministers whenever a U.S. citizen was born in Jerusalem, and that official letter from the Secretary of State said --  says just --  it announces that a new American has been born in Israel. Would that be constitutional?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: This is a law passed by Congress and it says every time a U.S. citizen is born in Jerusalem, the Secretary of State has to send an official letter to every other foreign minister saying that a new American has been born in Israel.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: That would be constitutional, even though the --  the Congress is basically telling the Secretary of State to engage in a certain kind of diplomatic communication with other foreign countries.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Yes, exactly right. That was going to be my point, that it was -- (Laughter).

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- that it was extremely similar to what a passport does, that both are forms of diplomatic communication, and that what we usually say about diplomatic communication is that whatever Congress's other foreign affairs powers are, the power of diplomatic communication belongs to the President and the President alone; that in that realm we only speak with one voice. And so I guess I have to sort of say that that answer that you gave me, that this could -- that Congress could say to the Secretary of State, here's the diplomatic communication that you have to send to other foreign ministers, seems, well, a little bit shocking.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So you would say in Justice Kagan's hypothetical, maybe the letter that's required to be sent to every foreign head of state would be unconstitutional, but that doesn't mean that the passport is, because the passport is used primarily for purposes of identification, and it's only the letter that makes it something else.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, if you say that --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Justice Kennedy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Do you want us to say in our opinion that this is not a political declaration?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, then, I'm not sure why that Congress passed it, then.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I thought it was a Federal crime to say that you were born in the United States when you weren't on an official document. So why -- why is it that it's okay for Congress to say something that hasn't happened, meaning to say that someone born in Jerusalem is actually born in Israel? It's different than somebody who's born in -- in Taiwan saying I was born in America.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I mean, they can self-identify all they want, but can they do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I know what it's done, but has the U.S. recognized -- has any President since recognized Israel's sovereignty over that area?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Ms. Lewin, may I just -- I know your time is -- but if I might just go back to the thought that the Chief Justice gave you that you agreed Alderson Reporting Company with. Here's the way a passport begins. It begins, "The Secretary of State of the United States of America hereby requests all who it may concern to permit the citizen," blah, blah, blah. That's what -- that's the -- you know, the Secretary of State requests all of these who are going to be looking at this passport. And then in Haig v. Agee, we described a passport as a letter of introduction in which the issuing sovereign vouches for the bearer and requests other sovereigns to aid the bearer. So this is, this passport, it seems, both on what it says itself and on what we've said about it, it's like a letter from the Secretary of State. It's a communication.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. General Verrilli.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What -- what if there were a law that said precisely pretty much what you just said? The law says, okay, Mr. President, you can recognize whoever you want, but if you recognize this -- this country, this government, we're going to treat it as if you hadn't recognized this government. For all purposes of domestic law, we're going to pretend -- we're going to operate on the assumption that you have recognized this country.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So -- so that law would be unconstitutional?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, isn't that exactly what the Taiwan Relations Act says? What it says is, "The absence of diplomatic recognition shall not affect the application of the laws of the United States with respect to Taiwan."

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, let's say the President --  let's say the President did not want to recognize Taiwan and Congress passes a law that says for every purpose under American law, we will treat Taiwan as if it had been recognized?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But is that really true? Suppose -- could Congress pass a law saying that every passport -- every passport issued to an American citizen must list the place of birth, including country, and that for this purpose, the country is the nation that issued the birth certificate to that individual? Could -- could Congress do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If it -- if it is within Congress's -- if it is within Congress's power, what difference does it make whether it antagonizes foreign countries?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And this may be one of them. So --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- the mere fact that it upsets foreign relations doesn't prove a thing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But why couldn't you have a disclaimer of the kind that I've explained to the Petitioners' counsel. She said that would be perfectly lawful, for you to say it's not the position of the State Department, this is not an indication that Israel is -- has jurisdiction over Jerusalem.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Why wouldn't that solve the problem?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: If it had -- if it were such a big deal, why did the Chief Executive at the time sign it?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So we should give no weight to the fact that the Chief Executive signed the law that he is now saying has such a dramatic -- that his successor, but I gather the position is the same -- is now saying has such deleterious effects on American foreign policy? Well, as a general matter, does that have any consequence at all? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Oh, no. I know, I'm not suggesting it does, although that's a separate question. But it does go to the credibility of the assertion that this is going to have such dramatic effects on American foreign policy.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But that's partly Alderson Reporting Company because the Executive Branch made such a big deal out of it. I mean, they issue a statement saying, this is unconstitutional and all that. They could easily have said, this is no big deal, they're just letting whoever is born there pick the name they want to put on --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- nothing to see here, move on, and we're proving that by going ahead and signing it. And over the -- over the intervening course, the executive has litigated this. It's a self-fulfilling prophecy that it's going to be such a huge deal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Not necessarily.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What they're asking you Alderson Reporting Company to do is to look -- they're asking the government to lie.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm not -- that's exactly what you're saying the government should -- the executive department should not do.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So how are we --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What if it just says "Disputed," parentheses after it, "Disputed"? Then I gather they wouldn't be lying. They would be telling the truth.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, it's disputed as a matter of the government of the United States. Alderson Reporting Company Part of the government says this -- well, actually, no, I mean, Congress is not saying under my hypothetical, this is Israel. It's saying there's a dispute about it, which I would think is about as true a statement as you can make.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Can you help me with this same question? How should we approach it generally? That is to say, I can think of instances where a similar statute is serving nothing other than administrative matters -- the passport should be red or something -- and I can think of instances where it causes a lot of trouble. But I can think of instances like this one, and I could and you could easily replicate this controversy with Israel in our imaginations, similar controversy with Donetsk and the Ukraine, where we make some agreement with Russia and something similar comes up, or with Iran, and pretend that -- remember that Russia once invaded the northern part of Iran. And all over the world there can be similar kinds of problems where it's debatable what the words of the passport Alderson Reporting Company actually mean or how they will be taken by others and what others will think they mean. Now, how do we, who know little about it, determine, when it gets into the realm, that we should stay out of it and let the President and the Constitution gives him that power or should -- some think we should always intervene, perhaps some never. What in your mind is the right standard? How do we decide?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: General Verrilli, if we agree with the Petitioner, we do not have to confront the constitutional question whether the President has exclusive power over recognition. If we agree with you, we are going to have to grapple with that constitutional Alderson Reporting Company question, right? So maybe you want to talk about it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But if it does, then their argument is going to be it does amount to a -- if it does contradict it, then Congress is making its own judgment about recognition. You have to confront that. Are they entitled to do that? I don't see how you can avoid that question. Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Couldn't you say that, at a minimum, the Petitioner has conceded that it is not clear that this is recognition?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: General Verrilli, it is -- the requirement of place of birth on the passport, that doesn't come from the Congress. That comes from the executive, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And I thought that the purpose of birthplace identified by the government, by the executive, is to identify the person and not -- it's not something that the President or the executive required out of a foreign policy concern. The purpose Alderson Reporting Company of it was to identify the individual; isn't that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: This is a pretty rough way to identify someone. I mean, there are hundreds of John Smith's in the United States.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Can I ask you the question I asked Ms. Lewin. What exactly is the position of the executive regarding Israel's exercise of sovereign powers in Jerusalem? Is it the case that it is the position of the executive that Israel cannot lawfully exercise any sovereign powers within Jerusalem?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, it must have been accepted as evidence of birth or the passport would never have been issued.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: I thought you had to provide a birth certificate --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: -- in order to get that.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Let's say there's a -- that passports are printed in Country A, not the United States, and there's a printing plant there, and Congress passes a law saying, no, you must have the passports printed in Country B because we don't think Alderson Reporting Company you should recognize Country A. Does that interfere with the President's recognition power?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Because Congress wished the President would not recognize Country A. So in response to that, we're directing that passports that are now printed in Country A be printed in Country B.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I thought your position was that the President has the exclusive right to decide what interferes with his recognition power.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: War making is an executive function, too.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: If I think that -- that Alderson Reporting Company Congress generally --  that Congress has the authority under the Constitution to require identification information in passports and to specify the identification information that's included, if I --  if I believe that, then the effect of your argument, I guess, is that something that Congress can do is unconstitutional if it affects the recognition power -- the President's recognition authority in --  in some way. Is that the --  is that --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I don't --  I don't like to, you know, just keep going back to the same thing. It seems to me that you could draft a statement that actually furthers your position. This passport does not indicate that the government of the United States and the Secretary of State recognize that Israel has Alderson Reporting Company sovereign jurisdiction over Israel, and you'd actually be making your case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Ms. Lewin answered, I think quite candidly --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But it doesn't further -- why doesn't it further it?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But just like the signing statement.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Just like the signing statement, which said precisely what Justice Kennedy suggested, that the Executive could do at this point.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: General Verrilli, I think the answer to the question that Ms. Lewin gave was that she said yes, the Executive could put that on the passport. But she also said Congress could then pass a law saying, this is antithetical to our view, and that doesn't have to be put on the passport. On the passport is just birthplace, Israel, period. Congress could pass that into law and counter whatever the President does.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But that law isn't in front of us.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: General, if I'm understanding your narrow holding, just so that we can underscore it, what you're saying is that Congress can't compel speech by the President with respect to foreign relations.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, you see, I -- I pick up this passport, and it says place of birth, Israel. Do I know whether this person was born in Jerusalem or in -- in Haifa?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So how does it -- how does it advertise to the world that -- that the President is contradicting himself? All you know is that the person was born in Israel. It could have been anywhere in Israel.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But it is not a communication contained in the passport itself, is it? You're just saying that -- that this -- this piece of legislation advertises to the world what the situation will be, but -- but you're not compelling the President to -- to say that this individual was born in Jerusalem and we're going to say he was born in Israel, because you can't tell that from the passport.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: General, in -- general, when I travel abroad and come back to the United States or when I go to a foreign country and they're stamping my passport, do they have forms that require you to identify the city?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I know that some of them do. I know that some of them do.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Why would that be so? No matter how this Court decides, everyone will know what the position of the President is. Everyone will know Alderson Reporting Company what Congress thought when they passed this legislation. Whatever we do, that's not going to be changed, and our decision isn't going to be based on any view that we may have about whether Jerusalem should be regarded as part of Israel or the capital of Israel. So why will there be any effect on foreign policy except by people who will misunderstand the situation, either -- either because they really don't understand it or they will exploit it in some way?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But Congress did that, so nothing that we do is going to change that or change what Congress thought.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, General. Ms. Lewin, you have four minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: No, it's not. It's the place of birth. If you say Israel, you believe that -- you're saying that you believe that person was born in Israel.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And there was a waiver --  and there was a waiver provided and every President has exercised the waiver.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: How could you tell me it's not a lie? You, the United States, are being asked to put on the passport that you believe the place of birth of this individual is Israel, and the government -- and the executive has said, no, we don't think it was Israel, we think it was Jerusalem.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But the individual is not the one issuing the passport. It's the government. The document says. This is a diplomatic exchange between sovereigns.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I take it, Ms. Lewin, when you say the West Bank, I take it you think that Congress could pass the identical statute with respect to a child born in Hebron, say.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: That that, too, is Israel?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Yes. Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Can I say that this seems a particularly unfortunate week to be making this kind of, "oh, it's no big deal" argument. I mean, history suggests that everything is a big deal with respect to the status of Jerusalem. And right now Jerusalem is a tinderbox because of issues about the status of and access to a particularly holy site there. And so sort of everything matters, doesn't it? Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank The case is submitted.
